descript.abstract: Polygon objects representing ecological districts. This information resource comprises a digital dataset of the boundaries on the 1:500,000 published maps of ecological regions and ecological districts of New Zealand, which are part of McEwen (1987) (refer related resources). Ecological regions and districts are subdivisions of New Zealand into contiguous and discrete areas that have relatively homogenous physical (climate, soil, topography, geology) and biological characteristics (including cultural pattern, i.e. land use). Ecological regions are generally an aggregate of adjacent ecological districts with very closely related characteristics. Note that some ecological districts that are very distinct have been given the status of ecological region to emphasis their uniqueness; for example, Tongariro Ecological District is also Tongariro Ecological Region.
descript.purpose: Function: Preservation/protection; natural heritage; Science/research; Education Audience: Natural heritage managers; Scientists; Students
descript.supplinf: Ecological districts are not unique, ie: each named district can be comprised of more than 1 disjoint polygon and can have the same ecological code. An example is the ecological district name "Cook Strait", which is made up of 11 separate polygon entries in the geodatabase. The information resource contains boundaries of all of the ecological regions and districts in McEwen 1987 (refer related resources). Note that DoC staff in Northland developed an alternative framework of ecological regions and districts, which they currently use. The different ecological district boundaries are not reflected in this information source. This information resource was prepared by digitising the boundaries of 1:500,000 published maps of ecological regions and ecological districts of New Zealand, which are part of McEwen (1987) (refer related resources). The digital layer is derived from: McEwen W Mary 1987 Ecological regions and districts of New Zealand: third revised edition in four 1:500,000 maps. New Zealand Biological Resources Centre Publication no. 5 (in four parts). Department of Conservation, Wellington. ISBN: 0-478-01000-1. Ecological regions and districts have been adopted and extensively used by the Department of Conservation and many local authorities as a spatial framework for assessing significance and how well the protected area network represents a wider area. Over the past few years Landcare Research has been funded, primarily by the Foundation for Research, Science and Technology and the Ministry for the Environment, to develop "environmental domains." The results of this work strongly suggest that domains are likely to replace ecological districts as the preferred environmental classification framework for environmental classification and planning.

sngdate.caldate: The paper maps from which the digital layer was compiled were published in 1987.

theme.themekt: REQUIRED: Reference to a formally registered thesaurus or a similar authoritative source of theme keywords.

idinfo.accconst: Can be provided to any user on request, along with this metadata record and the accompanying disclaimers, guidelines for use of the information, and copyright obligations.
idinfo.useconst:
Disclaimers 1. DoC makes no express or implied warranties as to the accuracy or completeness of the data or information, nor its suitability for any purpose. Errors are inevitably part of any database, and can arise by a number of means, from errors during field data collection, to errors during data entry. 2. DoC makes no warranties or representations as to possible infringement upon copyrights or other intellectual property rights of others in the data or information. 3. DoC will not accept liability for any direct, indirect, special or consequential damages, losses or expenses howsoever arising and relating use, of or lack of use, of the data or information supplied.
Guidelines for Use of the Information 4. Care should be taken in deriving conclusions from any data or information supplied. 5. Any use of the data or information supplied should state when the data or information was acquired and that it may now be out-of-date. 6. Care should be taken when using the information to propose environmental management practices at specific sites. Where possible, the data and information should be checked on the ground. 7. Users should note that landowners often welcome the opportunity to be involved in the development of environmental management proposals, rather than to simply comment on a comprehensive draft proposal.
Copyright Obligations 8. All proprietary rights to the intellectual property in the data or information remain with the Crown as its sole property. 9. Modification of the data and information or the addition of the information does not confer copyright or any other form of property of the original material to a user. 10. All maps or reports that are derived from the data or information must acknowledge the Crown copyright, in the following way: Crown Copyright: Department of Conservation Te Papa Atawhai [year]. 11. This information resource may be passed onto another party, in either hard copy or electronic form. If a user does this, then it is recommended that they also supply this metadata record with the information resource.

metainfo.metstdn: FGDC Content Standards for Digital Geospatial Metadata

dataqual.logic:
It is unknown how well the digital boundaries match the ones on the paper maps.
The original ecological district boundaries were generated subjectively by ecological and environmental experts, based on their knowledge of the environmental homogeneity of sections of New Zealand. While all of the boundaries were originally delineated using the same line thickness, it is widely recognised that some boundaries are in reality narrower than others; e.g. narrow boundary along the foot of a steeply rising mountain range, and a broad boundary between high and low parts of alluvial plains. The ecological district boundary detail usually has been refined to 1:64,360 or 1:50,000 when a Protected Natural Area (PNA) Programme survey has been undertaken in an ecological district. These details are not reflected in this information resource. If detailed ecological district or region boundaries are required (e.g. at the property scale), then users should refer to the PNA Programme survey report.

dataIdInfo.idPurp: Function: Preservation/protection; natural heritage; Science/research; Education Audience: Natural heritage managers; Scientists; Students
dataIdInfo.idAbs:
Polygon objects representing ecological districts. This information resource comprises a digital dataset of the boundaries on the 1:500,000 published maps of ecological regions and ecological districts of New Zealand, which are part of McEwen (1987) (refer related resources). Ecological regions and districts are subdivisions of New Zealand into contiguous and discrete areas that have relatively homogenous physical (climate, soil, topography, geology) and biological characteristics (including cultural pattern, i.e. land use). Ecological regions are generally an aggregate of adjacent ecological districts with very closely related characteristics. Note that some ecological districts that are very distinct have been given the status of ecological region to emphasis their uniqueness; for example, Tongariro Ecological District is also Tongariro Ecological Region.

The district and region boundaries in Northland have been modifies as a result of the Protected Natural Area surveys of Northland highlighting significant issues. Dr Fred Brook reclassified Northland. The unpublished report on this can be found in the Department of Conservations document management system. DOCDM-250605These changes have been edited into this layer so that it shows current mapping. (Terry Conaghan)

27 May 2020 Ecological Code 50.07 Ecological District amended Dart to Karangarua,Ecological Region Aspiring to Whataroa (Doug Anderson on instruction of James Kinney)
